110 That won the vex'd virago to his will;
111 Who raving came; — then talk'd in milder strain, —
112 Then wept, then drank, and pledged her spouse again.
113 Such were his themes: how knaves o'er laws prevail,
114 Or, when made captives, how they fly from jail;
115 The young how brave, how subtle were the old:
116 And oaths attested all that Folly told.
117 On death like his what name shall we bestow,
118 So very sudden! yet so very slow?
119 'T was slow: — Disease, augmenting year by year,
120 Show'd the grim king by gradual steps brought near:
121 'T was not less sudden; in the night he died,
122 He drank, he swore, he jested, and he lied;
123 Thus aiding folly with departing breath: —
124 "Beware, Lorenzo, the slow-sudden death."
[Page 205]
125 Next died the Widow Goe, an active dame,
126 Famed ten miles round, and worthy all her fame;
127 She lost her husband when their loves were young,
128 But kept her farm, her credit, and her tongue:
129 Full thirty years she ruled, with matchless skill,
130 With guiding judgment and resistless will;
131 Advice she scorn'd, rebellions she suppress'd,
132 And sons and servants bow'd at her behest.
133 Like that great man's, who to his Saviour came,
134 Were the strong words of this commanding dame; —
135 "Come," if she said, they came; if "go," were gone;
136 And if "do this," — that instant it was done:
137 Her maidens told she was all eye and ear,
138 In darkness saw and could at distance hear; —
139 No parish-business in the place could stir,
140 Without direction or assent from her;
141 In turn she took each office as it fell,
142 Knew all their duties and discharged them well;
143 The lazy vagrants in her presence shook,
144 And pregnant damsels fear'd her stern rebuke;
145 She look'd on want with judgment clear and cool,
146 And felt with reason and bestow'd by rule;
147 She match'd both sons and daughters to her mind,
148 And lent them eyes, for Love, she heard, was blind;
149 Yet ceaseless still she throve, alert, alive,
150 The working bee, in full or empty hive;
[Page 206]
151 Busy and careful, like that working bee,
152 No time for love nor tender cares had she;
153 But when our farmers made their amorous vows,
154 She talk'd of market-steeds and patent-ploughs.
155 Not unemploy'd her evenings pass'd away,
156 Amusement closed, as business waked the day;
157 When to her toilet's brief concern she ran,
158 And conversation with her friends began,
159 Who all were welcome, what they saw, to share;
160 And joyous neighbours praised her Christmas fare,
161 That none around might, in their scorn, complain
162 Of Gossip Goe as greedy in her gain.
163 Thus long she reign'd, admired, if not approved;
164 Praised, if not honour'd; fear'd, if not beloved; —
165 When, as the busy days of Spring drew near,
166 That call'd for all the forecast of the year;
167 When lively hope the rising crops survey'd,
168 And April promised what September paid;
169 When stray'd her lambs where gorse and greenweed grow;
170 When rose her grass in richer vales below;
171 When pleased she look'd on all the smiling land,
172 And view'd the hinds, who wrought at her command;
173 (Poultry in groups still follow'd where she went;)
174 Then dread o'ercame her, — that her days were spent.
175 "Bless me! I die, and not a warning giv'n, —
176 " With much to do on Earth, and all for Heav'n! —
177 "No reparation for my soul's affairs,
178 " No leave petition'd for the barn's repairs;
179 "Accounts perplex'd, my interest yet unpaid,
180 " My mind unsettled, and my will unmade; —
[Page 207]
181 "A lawyer haste, and in your way, a priest;
182 " And let me die in one good work at least. "
183 She spake, and, trembling, dropp'd upon her knees,
184 Heaven in her eye and in her hand her keys;
185 And still the more she found her life decay,
186 With greater force she grasp'd those signs of sway:
187 Then fell and died! — In haste her sons drew near,
188 And dropp'd, in haste, the tributary tear,
189 Then from th' adhering clasp the keys unbound,
190 And consolation for their sorrows found.
191 Death has his infant-train; his bony arm
192 Strikes from the baby-cheek the rosy charm;
193 The brightest eye his glazing film makes dim,
194 And his cold touch sets fast the lithest limb:
195 He seized the sick'ning boy to Gerard lent,
196 When three days 'life, in feeble cries, were spent;
197 In pain brought forth, those painful hours to stay,
198 To breathe in pain and sigh its soul away!
199 "But why thus lent, if thus recall'd again,
200 " To cause and feel, to live and die in, pain? "
201 Or rather say, Why grievous these appear,
202 If all it pays for Heaven's eternal year;
203 If these sad sobs and piteous sighs secure
204 Delights that live, when worlds no more endure?
205 The sister-spirit long may lodge below,
206 And pains from nature, pains from reason, know;
207 Through all the common ills of life may run,
208 By hope perverted and by love undone;
209 A wife's distress, a mother's pangs, may dread,
210 And widow-tears, in bitter anguish, shed;
[Page 208]
211 May at old age arrive through numerous harms,
212 With children's children in those feeble arms:
213 Nor till by years of want and grief oppress'd
214 Shall the sad spirit flee and be at rest!
215 Yet happier therefore shall we deem the boy,
216 Secured from anxious care and dangerous joy?
217 Not so! for then would Love Divine in vain
218 Send all the burthens weary men sustain;
219 All that now curb the passions when they rage,
220 The checks of youth and the regrets of age;
221 All that now bid us hope, believe, endure,
222 Our sorrow's comfort and our vice's cure;
223 All that for Heaven's high joys the spirits train,
224 And charity, the crown of all, were vain.
225 Say, will you call the breathless infant blest,
226 Because no cares the silent grave molest?
227 So would you deem the nursling from the wing
228 Untimely thrust and never train'd to sing;
229 But far more blest the bird whose grateful voice
230 Sings its own joy and makes the woods rejoice,
231 Though, while untaught, ere yet he charm'd the ear,
232 Hard were his trials and his pains severe!
233 Next died the Lady who yon Hall possess'd;
234 And here they brought her noble bones to rest.
[Page 209]
235 In Town she dwelt; — forsaken stood the Hall:
236 Worms ate the floors, the tap'stry fled the wall:
237 No fire the kitchen's cheerless grate display'd;
238 No cheerful light the long-closed sash convey'd;
239 The crawling worm, that turns a summer-fly,
240 Here spun his shroud and laid him up to die
241 The winter-death: — upon the bed of state,
242 The bat shrill shrieking woo'd his flickering mate;
243 To empty rooms the curious came no more,
244 From empty cellars turn'd the angry poor,
245 And surly beggars cursed the ever-bolted door.
246 To one small room the steward found his way,
247 Where tenants follow'd to complain and pay;
248 Yet no complaint before the Lady came,
249 The feeling servant spared the feeble dame;
250 Who saw her farms with his observing eyes,
251 And answer'd all requests with his replies: —
252 She came not down, her falling groves to view;
253 Why should she know, what one so faithful knew?
254 Why come, from many clamorous tongues to hear,
255 What one so just might whisper in her ear?
256 Her oaks or acres, why with care explore;
257 Why learn the wants, the sufferings of the poor;
258 When one so knowing all their worth could trace,
259 And one so piteous govern'd in her place?
[Page 210]
260 Lo! now, what dismal Sons of Darkness come,
261 To bear this Daughter of Indulgence home;
262 Tragedians all, and well-arranged in black!
263 Who nature, feeling, force, expression lack;
264 Who cause no tear, but gloomily pass by,
265 And shake their sables in the wearied eye,
266 That turns disgusted from the pompous scene,
267 Proud without grandeur, with profusion, mean!
268 The tear for kindness past affection owes;
269 For worth deceased the sigh from reason flows;
270 E'en well-feign'd passion for our sorrows call,
271 And real tears for mimic miseries fall:
272 But this poor farce has neither truth nor art,
273 To please the fancy or to touch the heart;
274 Unlike the darkness of the sky, that pours
275 On the dry ground its fertilising showers;
276 Unlike to that which strikes the soul with dread,
277 When thunders roar and forky fires are shed;
278 Dark but not awful, dismal but yet mean,
279 With anxious bustle moves the cumbrous scene;
280 Presents no objects tender or profound,
281 But spreads its cold unmeaning gloom around.
282 When woes are feign'd, how ill such forms appear
283 And oh! how needless, when the wo's sincere.
284 Slow to the vault they come, with heavy tread,
285 Bending beneath the Lady and her lead;
286 A case of elm surrounds that ponderous chest,
287 Close on that case the crimson velvet's press'd;
288 Ungenerous this, that to the worm denies,
289 With niggard-caution, his appointed prize;
290 For now, ere yet he works his tedious way,
291 Through cloth and wood and metal to his prey,
[Page 211]
292 That prey dissolving shall a mass remain,
293 That fancy loathes and worms themselves disdain.
294 But see! the master-mourner makes his way,
295 To end his office for the coffin'd clay;
296 Pleased that our rustic men and maids behold
297 His plate like silver, and his studs like gold,
298 As they approach to spell the age, the name,
299 And all the titles of th' illustrious dame. —
300 This as (my duty done) some scholar read,
301 A Village-father look'd disdain and said:
302 "Away, my friends! why take such pains to know
303 " What some brave marble soon in Church shall show?
304 "Where not alone her gracious name shall stand,
305 " But how she lived — the blessing of the land;
306 "How much we all deplored the noble dead,
307 " What groans we utter'd and what tears we shed;
308 "Tears, true as those, which in the sleepy eyes
309 " Of weeping cherubs on the stone shall rise;
310 "Tears, true as those which, ere she found her grave,
311 " The noble Lady to our sorrows gave. "
312 Down by the church-way walk, and where the brook
313 Winds round the chancel like a shepherd's crook;
314 In that small house, with those green pales before,
315 Where jasmine trails on either side the door;
316 Where those dark shrubs, that now grow wild at will,
317 Were clipp'd in form and tantalised with skill;
318 Where cockles blanch'd and pebbles neatly spread,
319 Form'd shining borders for the larkspurs 'bed; —
320 There lived a Lady, wise, austere, and nice,
321 Who show'd her virtue by her scorn of vice;
[Page 212]
322 In the dear fashions of her youth she dress'd,
323 A pea-green Joseph was her favourite vest;
324 Erect she stood, she walk'd with stately mien,
325 Tight was her length of stays, and she was tall and lean.
326 There long she lived in maiden-state immured,
327 From looks of love and treacherous man secured;
328 Though evil fame — (but that was long before)
329 Had blown her dubious blast at Catherine's door.
330 A Captain thither, rich from India came,
331 And though a cousin call'd, it touch'd her fame:
332 Her annual stipend rose from his behest,
333 And all the long-prized treasures she possess'd: —
334 If aught like joy awhile appear'd to stay
335 In that stern face, and chase those frowns away;
336 'Twas when her treasures she disposed for view
337 And heard the praises to their splendour due;
338 Silks beyond price, so rich, they'd stand alone,
339 And diamonds blazing on the buckled zone;
340 Rows of rare pearls by curious workmen set,
341 And bracelets fair in box of glossy jet;
342 Bright polish'd amber precious from its size,
343 Or forms the fairest fancy could devise:
344 Her drawers of cedar, shut with secret springs,
345 Conceal'd the watch of gold and rubied rings;
346 Letters, long proofs of love, and verses fine
347 Round the pink'd rims of crisped Valentine.
348 Her china-closet, cause of daily care,
349 For woman's wonder held her pencill'd ware;
350 That pictured wealth of China and Japan,
351 Like its cold mistress, shunn'd the eye of man.
[Page 213]
352 Her neat small room, adorn'd with maiden-taste,
353 A clipp'd French puppy, first of favourites, graced:
354 A parrot next, but dead and stuff'd with art;
355 (For Poll, when living, lost the Lady's heart,
356 And then his life; for he was heard to speak
357 Such frightful words as tinged his Lady's cheek:)
358 Unhappy bird! who had no power to prove,
359 Save by such speech, his gratitude and love.
360 A grey old cat his whiskers lick'd beside;
361 A type of sadness in the house of pride.
362 The polish'd surface of an India chest,
363 A glassy globe, in frame of ivory, press'd;
364 Where swam two finny creatures; one of gold,
365 Of silver one; both beauteous to behold: —
366 All these were form'd the guiding taste to suit;
367 The beast well-manner'd and the fishes mute.
368 A widow'd Aunt was there, compell'd by need
369 The nymph to flatter and her tribe to feed;
370 Who, veiling well her scorn, endured the clog,
371 Mute as the fish and fawning as the dog.
372 As years increased, these treasures, her delight,
373 Arose in value in their owner's sight:
374 A miser knows that, view it as he will,
375 A guinea kept is but a guinea still:
376 And so he puts it to its proper use,
377 That something more this guinea may produce;
378 But silks and rings, in the possessor's eyes,
379 The oft'ner seen, the more in value rise,
380 And thus are wisely hoarded to bestow
381 The kind of pleasure that with years will grow.
382 But what avail'd their worth — if worth had they —
383 In the sad summer of her slow decay?
[Page 214]
384 Then we beheld her turn an anxious look
385 From trunks and chests, and fix it on her book, —
386 A rich-bound Book of Prayer the Captain gave,
387 (Some Princess had it, or was said to have;)
388 And then once more, on all her stores, look round,
389 And draw a sigh so piteous and profound,
390 That told, "Alas! how hard from these to part,
391 " And for new hopes and habits form the heart!
392 "What shall I do (she cried), my peace of mind
393 " To gain in dying, and to die resign'd? "
394 "Hear," we return'd; — "these baubles cast aside,
395 " Nor give thy God a rival in thy pride;
396 "Thy closets shut, and ope thy kitchen's door;
397 " There own thy failings, here invite the poor;
398 "A friend of Mammon let thy bounty make;
399 " For widow's prayers, thy vanities forsake;
400 "And let the hungry, of thy pride partake
401 " Then shall thy inward eye with joy survey
402 "The angel Mercy tempering Death's delay!"
403 Alas! 'twas hard; the treasures still had charms,
404 Hope still its flattery, sickness its alarms;
405 Still was the same unsettled, clouded view,
406 And the same plaintive cry, "What shall I do?"
407 Nor change appear'd; for when her race was run,
408 Doubtful we all exclaim'd, "What has been done?"
409 Apart she lived, and still she lies alone,
410 Yon earthy heap awaits the flattering stone,
411 On which invention shall be long employ'd,
412 To show the various worth of Catherine Lloyd.
413 Next to these ladies, but in nought allied,
414 A noble Peasant, Isaac Ashford, died.
[Page 215]
415 Noble he was, contemning all things mean,
416 His truth unquestion'd and his soul serene:
417 Of no man's presence Isaac felt afraid;
418 At no man's question Isaac look'd dismay'd:
419 Shame knew him not, he dreaded no disgrace;
420 Truth, simple truth, was written in his face;
421 Yet while the serious thought his soul approved,
422 Cheerful he seem'd, and gentleness he loved,
423 To bliss domestic he his heart resign'd,
424 And with the firmest had the fondest mind:
425 Were others joyful, he look'd smiling on,
426 And gave allowance where he needed none;
427 Good he refused with future ill to buy,
428 Nor knew a joy that caused reflection's sigh;
429 A friend to virtue, his unclouded breast
430 No envy stung, no jealousy distress'd;
431 (Bane of the poor! it wounds their weaker mind,
432 To miss one favour, which their neighbours find:)
433 Yet far was he from stoic pride removed;
434 He felt humanely, and he warmly loved:
435 I mark'd his action, when his infant died,
436 And his old neighbour for offence was tried;
437 The still tears, stealing down that furrow'd cheek,
438 Spoke pity, plainer than the tongue can speak.
439 If pride were his, 't was not their vulgar pride
440 Who, in their base contempt, the great deride;
441 Nor pride in learning, — though my Clerk agreed,
442 If fate should call him, Ashford might succeed;
443 Nor pride in rustic skill, although we knew,
444 None his superior, and his equals few: —
445 But if that spirit in his soul had place,
446 It was the jealous pride that shuns disgrace;
[Page 216]
447 A pride in honest fame, by virtue gain'd,
448 In sturdy boys to virtuous labours train'd;
449 Pride in the power that guards his country's coast,
450 And all that Englishmen enjoy and boast;
451 Pride, in a life that slander's tongue defied, —
452 In fact a noble passion, misnamed Pride.
453 He had no party's rage, no sect'ry's whim:
454 Christian and countrymen was all with him:
455 True to his church he came; no Sunday-shower
456 Kept him at home in that important hour;
457 Nor his firm feet could one persuading sect,
458 By the strong glare of their new light direct; —
459 "On hope, in mine own sober light, I gaze,
460 " But should be blind, and lose it, in your blaze. "
461 In times severe, when many a sturdy swain
462 Felt it his pride, his comfort, to complain;
463 Isaac their wants would soothe, his own would hide,
464 And feel in that his comfort and his pride.
465 At length he found, when seventy years were run,
466 His strength departed, and his labour done;
467 When he, save honest fame, retain'd no more,
468 But lost his wife, and saw his children poor:
469 'T was then, a spark of — say not discontent —
470 Struck on his mind, and thus he gave it vent: —
471 "Kind are your laws, ('t is not to be denied,)
472 " That in yon House, for ruin'd age, provide,
473 "And they are just; — when young, we give you all,
474 " And for assistance in our weakness call. —
475 "Why then this proud reluctance to be fed,
476 " To join your poor, and eat the parish-bread?
477 "But yet I linger, loth with him to feed,
478 " Who gains his plenty by the sons of need
[Page 217]
479 "He who, by contract, all your paupers took,
480 " And gauges stomachs with an anxious look:
481 "On some old master I could well depend;
482 " See him with joy and thank him as a friend;
483 "But ill on him, who doles the day's supply,
484 " And counts our chances who at night may die:
485 "Yet help me, Heav'n! and let me not complain
486 " Of what I suffer, but my fate sustain. "
487 Such were his thoughts, and so resign'd he grew;
488 Daily he placed the Workhouse in his view!
489 But came not there, for sudden was his fate,
490 He dropp'd, expiring, at his cottage-gate.
491 I feel his absence in the hours of prayer,
492 And view his seat and sigh for Isaac there:
493 I see no more those white locks thinly spread
494 Round the bald polish of that honour'd head;
495 No more that awful glance on playful wight,
496 Compell'd to kneel and tremble at the sight,
497 To fold his fingers, all in dread the while,
498 Till Mister Ashford soften'd to a smile;
499 No more that meek and suppliant look in prayer,
500 Nor the pure faith (to give it force), are there: —
501 But he is blest, and I lament no more
502 A wise good man contented to be poor.
503 Then died a Rambler; not the one who sails
504 And trucks, for female favours, beads and nails;
[Page 218]
505 Not one, who posts from place to place — of men
506 And manners treating with a flying pen;
507 Not he, who climbs, for prospects, Snowdon's height,
508 And chides the clouds that intercept the sight;
509 No curious shell, rare plant, or brilliant spar,
510 Enticed our traveller from his home so far;
511 But all the reason, by himself assign'd
512 For so much rambling, was, a restless mind;
513 As on, from place to place, without intent,
514 Without reflection, Robin Dingley went.
515 Not thus by nature: — never man was found
516 Less prone to wander from his parish bound:
517 Claudian's Old Man, to whom all scenes were new,
518 Save those where he and where his apples grew,
519 Resembled Robin, who around would look,
520 And his horizon for the earth's mistook.
521 To this poor swain a keen Attorney came; —
522 "I give thee joy, good fellow! on thy name;
[Page 219]
523 " The rich old Dingley's dead; — no child has he,
524 "Nor wife, nor will; his all is left for thee:
525 " To be his fortune's heir thy claim is good;
526 "Thou hast the name, and we will prove the blood."
527 The claim was made; 't was tried, — it would not stand;
528 They proved the blood, but were refused the land
529 Assured of wealth, this man of simple heart,
530 To every friend had predisposed a part:
531 His wife had hopes indulged of various kind;
532 The three Miss Dingleys had their school assign'd,
533 Masters were sought for what they each required,
534 And books were bought and harpsichords were hired;
535 So high was hope: — the failure touch'd his brain,
536 And Robin never was himself again;
537 Yet he no wrath, no angry wish express'd,
538 But tried, in vain, to labour or to rest;
539 Then cast his bundle on his back and went
540 He knew not whither, nor for what intent.
541 Years fled; — of Robin all remembrance past,
542 When home he wander'd in his rags at last:
543 A sailor's jacket on his limbs was thrown,
544 A sailor's story he had made his own;
545 Had suffer'd battles, prisons, tempests, storms,
546 Encountering death in all his ugliest forms:
547 His cheeks were haggard, hollow was his eye
548 Where madness lurk'd, conceal'd in misery;
549 Want, and th' ungentle world, had taught a part,
550 And prompted cunning to that simple heart:
551 "He now bethought him, he would roam no more,
552 But live at home and labour as before."
[Page 220]
553 Here clothed and fed, no sooner he began
554 To round and redden, than away he ran;
555 His wife was dead, their children past his aid.
556 So, unmolested, from his home he stray'd:
557 Six years elapsed, when, worn with want and pain,
558 Came Robin, wrapt in all his rags, again: —
559 We chide, we pity; — placed among our poor,
560 He fed again, and was a man once more.
561 As when a gaunt and hungry fox is found,
562 Entrapp'd alive in some rich hunter's ground:
563 Fed for the field, although each day's a feast,
564 Fatten you may, but never tame the beast;
565 A house protects him, savoury viands sustain;
566 But loose his neck and off he goes again:
567 So stole our Vagrant from his warm retreat,
568 To rove a prowler and be deem'd a cheat.
569 Hard was his fare; for him at length we saw,
570 In cart convey'd and laid supine on straw.
571 His feeble voice now spoke a sinking heart;
572 His groans now told the motions of the cart;
573 And when it stopp'd, he tried in vain to stand;
574 Closed was his eye, and clench'd his clammy hand;
575 Life ebb'd apace, and our best aid no more
576 Could his weak sense or dying heart restore:
577 But now he fell, a victim to the snare,
578 That vile attorneys for the weak prepare; —
579 They who, when profit or resentment call,
580 Heed not the groaning victim they enthrall.
581 Then died lamented, in the strength of life,
582 A valued Mother and a faithful Wife;
[Page 221]
583 Call'd not away, when time had loosed each hold
584 On the fond heart, and each desire grew cold;
585 But when, to all that knit us to our kind,
586 She felt fast-bound, as charity can bind; —
587 Not when the ills of age, its pain, its care,
588 The drooping spirit for its fate prepare;
589 And, each affection failing, leaves the heart
590 Loosed from life's charm, and willing to de part;
591 But all her ties the strong invader broke,
592 In all their strength, by one tremendous stroke!
593 Sudden and swift the eager pest came on,
594 And terror grew, till every hope was gone;
595 Still those around appear'd for hope to seek!
596 But view'd the sick and were afraid to speak. —
597 Slowly they bore, with solemn step, the dead;
598 When grief grew loud and bitter tears were shed
599 My part began; a crowd drew near the place,
600 Awe in each eye, alarm in every face:
601 So swift the ill, and of so fierce a kind,
602 That fear with pity mingled in each mind;
603 Friends with the husband came their griefs to blend;
604 For good-man Frankford was to all a friend.
605 The last-born boy they held above the bier,
606 He knew not grief, but cries express'd his fear;
607 Each different age and sex reveal'd its pain,
608 In now a louder, now a lower strain;
609 While the meek father, listening to their tones,
610 Swell'd the full cadence of the grief by groans.
611 The elder sister strove her pangs to hide,
612 And soothing words to younger minds applied:
613 "Be still, be patient;" oft she strove to stay;
614 But fail'd as oft, and weeping turn'd away.
[Page 222]
615 Curious and sad, upon the fresh-dug hill,
616 The village lads stood melancholy still;
617 And idle children, wandering to and fro,
618 As Nature guided, took the tone of wo.
619 Arrived at home, how then they gazed around,
620 In every place, — where she — no more, was found; —
621 The seat at table she was wont to fill;
622 The fire-side chair, still set, but vacant still;
623 The garden-walks, a labour all her own;
624 The latticed bower, with trailing shrubs o'ergrown;
625 The Sunday-pew she fill'd with all her race, —
626 Each place of hers, was now a sacred place,
627 That, while it call'd up sorrows in the eyes,
628 Pierced the full heart and forced them still to rise.
629 Oh sacred sorrow! by whom souls are tried,
630 Sent not to punish mortals, but to guide;
[Page 223]
631 If thou art mine, (and who shall proudly dare
632 To tell his Maker, he has had his share?)
633 Still let me feel for what thy pangs are sent,
634 And be my guide and not my punishment!
635 Of Leah Cousins next the name appears,
636 With honours crown'd and blest with length of years,
637 Save that she lived to feel, in life's decay,
638 The pleasure die, the honours drop away;
639 A matron she, whom every village-wife
640 View'd as the help and guardian of her life;
641 Fathers and sons, indebted to her aid,
642 Respect to her and her profession paid;
643 Who in the house of plenty largely fed,
644 Yet took her station at the pauper's bed;
645 Nor from that duty could be bribed again,
646 While fear or danger urged her to remain:
647 In her experience all her friends relied,
648 Heaven was her help and nature was her guide.
649 Thus Leah lived; long trusted, much caress'd,
650 Till a Town-Dame a youthful Farmer bless'd;
651 A gay vain bride, who would example give
652 To that poor village where she deign'd to live;
653 Some few months past, she sent, in hour of need,
654 For Doctor Glibb, who came with wond'rous speed:
655 Two days he waited, all his art applied,
656 To save the mother when her infant died: —
657 "'Twas well I came," at last he deign'd to say;
658 "'Twas wond'rous well;" — and proudly rode away.
659 The news ran round; — "How vast the Doctor's pow'r!"
660 "He saved the Lady in the trying hour;
[Page 224]
661 " Saved her from death, when she was dead to hope,
662 "And her fond husband had resign'd her up:
663 " So all, like her, may evil fate defy,
664 "If Doctor Glibb, with saving hand, be nigh."
665 Fame (now his friend), fear, novelty, and whim,
666 And fashion, sent the varying sex to him:
667 From this, contention in the village rose;
668 And these the Dame espoused; the Doctor those:
669 The wealthier part, to him and science went;
670 With luck and her the poor remain'd content.
671 The Matron sigh'd; for she was vex'd at heart,
672 With so much profit, so much fame, to part:
673 "So long successful in my art," she cried,
674 "And this proud man, so young and so untried!"
675 "Nay," said the Doctor, "dare you trust your wives
676 " The joy, the pride, the solace of your lives,
677 "To one who acts and knows no reason why,
678 " But trusts, poor hag! to luck for an ally? —
679 "Who, on experience, can her claims advance,
680 " And own the powers of accident and chance?
681 "A whining dame, who prays in danger's view,
682 " (A proof she knows not what beside to do;)
683 "What's her experience? In the time that's gone,
684 " Blundering she wrought and still she blunders on: —
685 "And what is Nature? One who acts in aid
686 " Of gossips half asleep, and half afraid:
687 "With such allies I scorn my fame to blend,
688 " Skill is my luck and courage is my friend:
689 "No slave to Nature, 'tis my chief delight
690 " To win my way and act in her despite: —
691 "Trust then my art, that, in itself complete,
692 " Needs no assistance and fears no defeat. "
[Page 225]
693 Warm'd by her well-spiced ale and aiding pipe,
694 The angry Matron grew for contest ripe.
695 "Can you," she said, "ungrateful and unjust,
696 " Before experience, ostentation trust!
697 "What is your hazard, foolish daughters, tell?
698 " If safe, you're certain; if secure, you're well:
699 "That I have luck must friend and foe confess,
700 " And what's good judgment but a lucky guess?
701 "He boasts, but what he can do: — will you run
702 " From me, your friend! who, all he boasts, have done?
703 "By proud and learned words his powers are known;
704 " By healthy boys and handsome girls my own:
705 "Wives! fathers! children! by my help you live;
706 " Has this pale Doctor more than life to give?
707 "No stunted cripple hops the village round;
708 " Your hands are active and your heads are sound:
709 "My lads are all your fields and flocks require;
710 " My lasses all those sturdy lads admire.
711 "Can this proud leech, with all his boasted skill,
712 " Amend the soul or body, wit or will?
713 "Does he for courts the sons of farmers frame,
714 " Or make the daughter differ from the dame?
715 "Or, whom he brings into this world of wo,
716 " Prepares he them their part to undergo?
717 "If not, this stranger from your doors repel,
718 " And be content to be and to be well. "
719 She spake; but, ah! with words too strong and plain;
720 Her warmth offended, and her truth was vain:
721 The many left her, and the friendly few,
722 If never colder, yet they older grew;
[Page 226]
723 Till, unemploy'd, she felt her spirits droop,
724 And took, insidious aid! th' inspiring cup;
725 Grew poor and peevish as her powers decay'd,
726 And propp'd the tottering frame with stronger aid, —
727 Then died! I saw our careful swains convey,
728 From this our changeful world, the Matron's clay,
729 Who to this world, at least, with equal care,
730 Brought them its changes, good and ill to share.
731 Now to his grave was Roger Cuff convey'd,
732 And strong resentment's lingering spirit laid.
733 Shipwreck'd in youth, he home return'd, and found
734 His brethren three — and thrice they wish'd him drown'd.
735 "Is this a landsman's love? Be certain then,
736 " We part for ever! "— and they cried," Amen! "
737 His words were truth's: — Some forty summers fled,
738 His brethren died; his kin supposed him dead:
739 Three nephews these, one sprightly niece, and one,
740 Less near in blood — they call'd him surly John;
741 He work'd in woods apart from all his kind,
742 Fierce were his looks and moody was his mind.
743 For home the sailor now began to sigh: —
744 "The dogs are dead, and I'll return and die;
745 " When all I have, my gains, in years of care,
746 "The younger Cuffs with kinder souls shall share —
747 " Yet hold! I'm rich; — with one consent they'll say,
748 "'You're welcome, Uncle, as the flowers in May.'
749 " No; I'll disguise me, be in tatters dress'd,
750 "And best befriend the lads who treat me best."
751 Now all his kindred, — neither rich nor poor, —
752 Kept the wolf want some distance from the door.
[Page 227]
753 In piteous plight he knock'd at George's gate,
754 And begg'd for aid, as he described his state: —
755 But stern was George; — "Let them who had thee strong,
756 " Help thee to drag thy weaken'd frame along;
757 "To us a stranger, while your limbs would move,
758 " From us depart, and try a stranger's love: —
759 "Ha! dost thou murmur?" — for, in Roger's throat,
760 Was "Rascal!" rising with disdainful note.
761 To pious James he then his prayer address'd; —
762 "Good-lack," quoth James, "thy sorrows pierce my breast;
763 " And, had I wealth, as have my brethren twain,
764 "One board should feed us and one roof contain:
765 " But plead I will thy cause and I will pray:
766 "And so farewell! Heaven help thee on thy way!"
767 "Scoundrel!" said Roger (but apart); — and told
768 His case to Peter; — Peter too was cold; —
769 "The rates are high; we have a-many poor;
770 " But I will think, "— he said, and shut the door.
771 Then the gay niece the seeming pauper press'd; —
772 "Turn, Nancy, turn, and view this form distress'd:
773 " Akin to thine is this declining frame,
774 "And this poor beggar claims an Uncle's name."
775 "Avaunt! begone!" the courteous maiden said,
776 "Thou vile impostor! Uncle Roger's dead:
777 " I hate thee, beast; thy look my spirit shocks;
778 "Oh! that I saw thee starving in the stocks!"
779 "My gentle niece!" he said — and sought the wood. —
780 "I hunger, fellow; prithee, give me food!"
[Page 228]
781 "Give! am I rich? This hatchet take, and try
782 " Thy proper strength, nor give those limbs the lie;
783 "Work, feed thyself, to thine own powers appeal,
784 " Nor whine out woes, thine own right-hand can heal;
785 "And while that hand is thine and thine a leg,
786 " Scorn of the proud or of the base to beg. "
787 "Come, surly John, thy wealthy kinsman view,"
788 Old Roger said; — "thy words are brave and true;
789 " Come, live with me: we'll vex those scoundrel-boys,
790 "And that prim shrew shall, envying, hear our joys. —
791 " Tobacco's glorious fume all day we'll share,
792 "With beef and brandy kill all kinds of care;
793 " We'll beer and biscuit on our table heap,
794 "And rail at rascals, till we fall asleep."
795 Such was their life; but when the woodman died,
796 His grieving kin for Roger's smiles applied —
797 In vain; he shut, with stern rebuke, the door,
798 And dying, built a refuge for the poor,
799 With this restriction, That no Cuff should share
800 One meal, or shelter for one moment there.
801 My Record ends: — But hark! e'en now I hear
802 The bell of death, and know not whose to fear:
803 Our farmers all, and all our hinds were well;
804 In no man's cottage danger seem'd to dwell: —
805 Yet death of man proclaim these heavy chimes,
806 For thrice they sound, with pausing space, three times.
807 "Go; of my Sexton seek, Whose days are sped? —
808 " What! he, himself! — and is old Dibble dead? "
[Page 229]
809 His eightieth year he reach'd, still undecay'd,
810 And rectors five to one close vault convey'd: —
811 But he is gone; his care and skill I lose,
812 And gain a mournful subject for my Muse:
813 His masters lost, he'd oft in turn deplore,
814 And kindly add, —" Heaven grant, I lose no more! "
815 Yet, while he spake, a sly and pleasant glance
816 Appear'd at variance with his complaisance:
817 For, as he told their fate and varying worth,
818 He archly look'd, —" I yet may bear thee forth. "
819 " When first "— (he so began) —" my trade I plied,
820 "Good master Addle was the parish-guide;
821 " His clerk and sexton, I beheld with fear,
822 "His stride majestic, and his frown severe;
823 " A noble pillar of the church he stood,
824 "Adorn'd with college-gown and parish hood:
825 " Then as he paced the hallow'd aisles about,
826 "He fill'd the seven-fold surplice fairly out!
827 " But in his pulpit wearied down with prayer,
828 "He sat and seem'd as in his study's chair;
829 " For while the anthem swell'd, and when it ceased,
830 "Th' expecting people view'd their slumbering priest:
831 " Who, dozing, died. — Our Parson Peele was next;
832 "'I will not spare you,' was his favourite text;
833 " Nor did he spare, but raised them many a pound;
834 "Ev'n me he mulct for my poor rood of ground;
835 " Yet cared he nought, but with a gibing speech,
836 "'What should I do,' quoth he, 'but what I preach?'
837 " His piercing jokes (and he'd a plenteous store)
838 "Were daily offer'd both to rich and poor;
[Page 230]
839 " His scorn, his love, in playful words he spoke;
840 "His pity, praise, and promise, were a joke:
841 " But though so young and blest with spirits high,
842 "He died as grave as any judge could die:
843 " The strong attack subdued his lively powers, —
844 "His was the grave, and Doctor Grandspear ours.
845 "Then were there golden times the village round;
846 " In his abundance all appear'd t' abound;
847 "Liberal and rich, a plenteous board he spread,
848 " E'en cool Dissenters at his table fed;
849 "Who wish'd and hoped, — and thought a man so kind
850 " A way to Heaven, though not their own, might find;
851 "To them, to all, he was polite and free,
852 " Kind to the poor, and, ah! most kind to me!
853 "'Ralph,' would he say, 'Ralph Dibble, thou art old;
854 "'That doublet fit, 'twill keep thee from the cold:
855 "' How does my sexton? — What! the times are hard;
856 "'Drive that stout pig, and pen him in thy yard.'
857 " But most, his rev'rence loved a mirthful jest: —
858 "'Thy coat is thin; why, man, thou'rt barely dress'd;
859 "'It's worn to th' thread: but I have nappy beer;
860 "' Clap that within, and see how they will wear! '
861 "Gay days were these; but they were quickly past:
862 " When first he came, we found he cou'dn't last:
863 "A whoreson cough (and at the fall of leaf)
864 " Upset him quite; — but what's the gain of grief?
[Page 231]
865 "Then came the Author-Rector: his delight
866 " Was all in books; to read them or to write:
867 "Women and men he strove alike to shun,
868 " And hurried homeward when his tasks were done:
869 "Courteous enough, but careless what he said,
870 " For points of learning he reserved his head;
871 "And when addressing either poor or rich,
872 " He knew no better than his cassock which:
873 "He, like an osier, was of pliant kind,
874 " Erect by nature, but to bend inclined;
875 "Not like a creeper falling to the ground,
876 " Or meanly catching on the neighbours round: —
877 "Careless was he of surplice, hood, and band, —
878 " And kindly took them as they came to hand
879 "Nor, like the doctor, wore a world of hat,
880 " As if he sought for dignity in that:
881 "He talk'd, he gave, but not with cautious rules:
882 " Nor turn'd from gipsies, vagabonds, or fools;
883 "It was his nature, but they thought it whim,
884 " And so our beaux and beauties turn'd from him:
885 "Of questions, much he wrote, profound and dark, —
886 " How spake the serpent, and where stopp'd the ark;
887 "From what far land the queen of Sheba came;
888 " Who Salem's Priest, and what his father's name;
889 "He made the Song of Songs its mysteries yield,
890 " And Revelations, to the world, reveal'd.
891 "He sleeps i' the aisle, — but not a stone records
892 " His name or fame, his actions or his words:
893 "And truth, your reverence, when I look around,
894 " And mark the tombs in our sepulchral ground
[Page 232]
895 "(Though dare I not of one man's hope to doubt),
896 " I'd join the party who repose without.
897 "Next came a Youth from Cambridge, and, in truth,
898 " He was a sober and a comely youth;
899 "He blush'd in meekness as a modest man,
900 " And gain'd attention ere his task began;
901 "When preaching, seldom ventured on reproof,
902 " But touch'd his neighbours tenderly enough.
903 "Him, in his youth, a clamorous sect assail'd,
904 " Advised and censured, flatter'd, — and prevail'd. —
905 "Then did he much his sober hearers vex,
906 " Confound the simple, and the sad perplex;
907 "To a new style his reverence rashly took;
908 " Loud grew his voice, to threat'ning swell'd his look;
909 "Above, below, on either side, he gazed,
910 " Amazing all, and most himself amazed:
911 "No more he read his preachments pure and plain,
912 " But launch'd outright, and rose and sank again:
913 "At times he smiled in scorn, at times he wept,
914 " And such sad coil with words of vengeance kept,
915 "That our best sleepers started as they slept.
916 "'Conviction comes like lightning,' he would cry;
917 "'In vain you seek it, and in vain you fly;
918 "' 'T is like the rushing of the mighty wind,
919 "'Unseen its progress, but its power you find;
920 "'It strikes the child ere yet its reason wakes;
921 "' His reason fled, the ancient sire it shakes;
922 "'The proud, learn'd man, and him who loves to know
923 "'How and from whence these gusts of grace will blow,
[Page 233]
924 "' It shuns, — but sinners in their way impedes,
925 "'And sots and harlots visits in their deeds:
926 "'Of faith and penance it supplies the place;
927 "' Assures the vilest that they live by grace,
928 "'And, without running, makes them win the race.'
929 "Such was the doctrine our young prophet taught;
930 " And here conviction, there confusion wrought;
931 "When his thin cheek assumed a deadly hue,
932 " And all the rose to one small spot withdrew:
933 "They call'd it hectic; 't was a fiery flush,
934 " More fix'd and deeper than the maiden blush;
935 "His paler lips the pearly teeth disclosed,
936 " And lab'ring lungs the length'ning speech opposed.
937 "No more his span-girth shanks and quiv'ring thighs
938 " Upheld a body of the smaller size;
939 "But down he sank upon his dying bed,
940 'And gloomy crotchets fill'd his wandering head. —
941 "'Spite of my faith, all-saving faith,' he cried,
942 "'I fear of worldly works the wicked pride;
943 "' Poor as I am, degraded, abject, blind,
944 "'The good I've wrought still rankles in my mind;
945 "'My alms-deeds all, and every deed I've done,
946 "' My moral-rags defile me every one;
947 "'It should not be: — what say'st thou? tell me, Ralph.'
948 " Quoth I, 'Your reverence, I believe, you're safe;
949 "' Your faith's your prop, nor have you pass'd such time
950 "'In life's good-works as swell them to a crime.
951 "'If I of pardon for my sins were sure,
952 "' About my goodness I would rest secure. '
953 "Such was his end; and mine approaches fast;
954 " I've seen my best of preachers, — and my last. "—
[Page 234]
955 He bow'd, and archly smiled at what he said,
956 Civil but sly: — "And is old Dibble dead?"
957 Yes! he is gone: and we are going all;
958 Like flowers we wither, and like leaves we fall; —
959 Here, with an infant, joyful sponsors come,
960 Then bear the new-made Christian to its home;
961 A few short years and we behold him stand,
962 To ask a blessing, with his bride in hand:
963 A few, still seeming shorter, and we hear
964 His widow weeping at her husband's bier: —
965 Thus, as the months succeed, shall infants take
966 Their names; thus parents shall the child forsake;
967 Thus brides again and bridegrooms blithe shall kneel,
968 By love or law compell'd their vows to seal,
969 Ere I again, or one like me, explore
970 These simple Annals of the Village Poor.
[Page 237]

Editorial principles

The text has been typographically modernized, but without any silent modernization of spelling, capitalization, or punctuation. The source of the text is given and all editorial interventions have been recorded in textual notes. Based on the electronic text originally produced by the ECCO-TCP project, this text has been edited to conform to the recommendations found in Level 5 of the Best Practices for TEI in Libraries version 3.0.
